content.text: The student adjusts the length of the pendulum until the distance \(d\) measured from the bottom of the support to the centre of the bob is \(90.0 \text{cm}\)
He displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings
He measures, and records in Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for 1 complete oscillation
Calculate a value for \(T^2\) and record in Table 1.1
The student repeats the procedure in (a) using a distance \(d = 45.0 \text{cm}\)
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum
Calculate a value for \(T^2\) and record in Table 1.1
Explain why timing 10 oscillations gives a more accurate result for the period \(T\) than timing 1 oscillation
Describe **one** technique that you use to improve accuracy when measuring the distance \(d\)
You may draw a diagram to help your description
Describe **one** technique that you use to improve accuracy when measuring the time \(t\) for 10 oscillations
The pendulum support is 40 cm above the bench. Estimate the distance \(x\) between the bottom of the pendulum support and the floor
A student plans to plot a graph of \(T^2\) against \(d\). Suggest suitable values of \(d\) that the student can use to obtain measurements that are sufficient for this task
A student investigates the period of a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 shows the set up
Fig. 1.1
The student uses a thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). Room temperature is \(23^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). Show clearly, on Fig. 2.1, the reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Fig. 2.2 shows the apparatus set up for the investigation

The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the metal container. She places the thermometer in the hot water in the container. She records the temperature at time \(t = 0\). She immediately starts a stop-watch
She records the temperature in Table 2.1 at 30 s intervals until she has seven sets of readings
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
Plot a graph of temperature \(\theta\) (y-axis) against time \(t\) (x-axis). Label your axes appropriately
You do not need to start the \(y\)-axis at 0. Draw the best-fit curve
A student states that the average rate of cooling of the water decreases as the temperature of the water approaches room temperature
State whether your graph line supports this suggestion. Explain your answer by reference to the shape of the graph line
statement
explanation
Explain why it is good practice to read the thermometer scale at right angles to the reading
Draw a measuring cylinder containing water. On your diagram show the line of sight you use to obtain an accurate reading of the volume of water
A student investigates the cooling of water in a metal container
On Fig. 3.2, measure the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the illuminated object
The student places the lens at a distance \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
He moves the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen
He measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
Describe **two** techniques that you use to obtain a clearly focused image
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation \(f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
Give your answer to three significant figures and include the unit
The object is brighter than the image. Complete the sentences to describe two other ways in which the image seen on the screen is different from the object
1 The image is
2 The image is
The student repeats the steps in **(b)** using a distance \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\)
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation \(f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
State and explain whether your results for the focal length \(f\) are equal within the limits of experimental accuracy
statement
explanation
A student investigates the image produced by a lens
Fig. 3.1 shows the set up
Fig. 3.2
A student investigates the current required to melt different fuse wires
Fig. 4.1 shows part of the circuit the student uses
The following equipment is also available:
<label> fuse wires with a selection of different diameters and metals (all with the same length)
metre ruler
ammeter
variable resistor
Plan an experiment to investigate how **one** factor affects the current required to melt a fuse wire
You do **not** need to write about safety precautions
In your plan:
<label> state the variable that you choose to investigate
<label> complete the circuit diagram on Fig. 4.1
<label> explain briefly how to do the investigation
<label> state a key variable to keep constant
<label> draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
<label> explain how to use your results to reach a conclusion
